name: Maya Nguyen
description: Maya is a 17-year-old first-generation Vietnamese American high school senior from Houston who approaches the college search like a project manager and a journalist combined. Curious, methodical, and financially cautious, she maps the landscape of majors, outcomes, and affordability before letting herself get emotionally attached to any school. She’s aiming for environmental engineering with a policy minor and prioritizes mid-size universities that offer strong co-op pipelines, robust undergraduate research, and generous need-based aid. Because travel is limited, she compensates with deep online sleuthing, reading Common Data Sets, comparing net price calculators, and attending virtual info sessions to probe for specifics on four-year graduation rates, first-destination outcomes, and support for first-gen students. Time is tight—she helps her parents translate mail and runs school club commitments—so she builds systems: color-coded task boards, reminder chains for recommendations, and writing sprints for essays. Maya is empathetic and community-minded; she funnels what she learns back to younger students at her school and to peers online. She is decisive but not impulsive, balancing gut feel with evidence. Her guiding belief: the “right fit” is where she can grow, afford to stay, and graduate with options. She’s comfortable emailing admissions officers, negotiating fee waivers, and asking precise questions about institutional aid. She weighs Early Action to keep options open and steers clear of binding commitments due to finances. When anxiety spikes, she breaks big tasks into measurable steps and rewards herself with small creative hobbies. By application season, Maya’s toolkit includes a spreadsheet of deadlines, a calendar of supplemental prompts, a scholarship tracker, and a script for teacher recommendation requests. She uses these not just to submit on time but to craft an authentic narrative about climate resilience, community service, and persistence.
example_behaviours: Builds a comparative spreadsheet ranking colleges by net price, co-op placement rates, undergraduate research availability, and distance from home
Runs a Notion board that links each school to its supplements, word counts, and deadlines with status tags like Draft, Peer-Reviewed, Final
Schedules 20-minute Sunday sessions to update a FAFSA/CSS Profile checklist and gather documents for her parents
Attends virtual info sessions and asks targeted questions about need-based aid renewal criteria and work-study availability
Exports deadlines to a shared Google Calendar that sends SMS reminders two weeks and two days before each due date
Requests fee waivers through counselors and admissions offices; tracks confirmations to prevent last-minute payment blocks
Hosts a mini workshop for juniors about reading the Common Data Set and interpreting % need met
Maintains a library of essay snippets (anecdotes, metaphors, activity reflections) to remix into targeted supplements
Uses Reddit and Discord cautiously—cross-checks any claim against official sources before acting
Volunteers at a community garden and photographs local flood mitigation projects, later weaving observations into her main essay
Works part-time on weekends at a café to save for application-related costs and demonstrates time management
Practices mindful pomodoro sessions (25/5) and takes breaks sketching native plants to keep stress in check
